captions.text:
The cab of the new FH series
has a completely new design.

It's larger, stronger
and more comfortable.

I would like to describe
the new Volvo FH cab

as a completely new standard
in the truck industry.

It's built around the driver,
while they're driving,

and also when resting
and living in the truck. It's outstanding.

One of the key factors
when developing the new cab

has been to improve
the driver's ergonomic workplace.

The result is a more comfortable seat,
which can be taken back an extra 4 cm.

A neck-tilt function has also
been added to the steering wheel,

which further enables the driver
to find a relaxing position.

By making the A-pillars more upright
and lowering the engine tunnel,

Volvo Trucks has also been able
to create a lot more room.

The new FH cab is almost 1 cubic metre
larger than the current FH.

That means that even I, who's almost
2 m tall, can stand straight in this cab.
That is good news for all tall drivers.

The bigger cab also means that the
survival area for the driver is bigger.

Other safety improvements
include an escape hatch,

which can be used
if the cab doors are blocked.

The hatch also works as a sunroof,
allowing more light in the cab.

The instrument panel
has a completely new design,

which improves both ergonomics
and safety for the driver,

since buttons and controls
are now always close to their fingertips.

The idea behind the design
of the new dashboard is, of course,

that everything should be within easy
access for the driver while driving,

so they don't need to take
their eyes off the road.

Naturally, the colours and the materials
in the cab have been carefully chosen

to harmonise with
the overall sense of Volvo quality.

Quality is one of Volvo's core values,
and we never compromise with that one.
It's reflected in this new Volvo FH cab,

both when it comes to design
and functionality.

I think that drivers will love it
in the future.

title: Volvo Trucks - A cab designed for the driver (new Volvo FH)

comments.author: mustafa GÜNDÜZ

comments.text:
Amazing design for the interior, I hope it comes to North America as well 
very soon. I had a Volvo VNL 2005 day cab before, and as much as I liked 
the rest of the truck , I completely disliked the reliability of 
it,regarding wiring,sensors,computer problems etc. At the time it seemed 
Volvo North America could not find the way for the European 24 Volt system 
to downgrade and adapt to the 12 volt North American electrics.I hear they 
are way better now.I just bought a Mack CXU 613 with a Volvo 13 litre 
engine/MP-8 Mack engine, and  i-shift/M-Drive transmission. I am keeping my 
fingers crossed, it will do the job for at least six years or so and then I 
might consider again going back to Volvo again.﻿

comments.text:
It's like you want to buy one even if it would be useless to you but just 
to have it ;) It's some great reading on their website. All the news and 
features are amazing. This is one hell of a truck, it's like a rolling top 
modern high tech hotel room. 

I drive it in "Euro Truck Simulator 2" and it's easily the best truck, it 
feels and behaves totally different in all positive way. The acc, power, 
handling, breaking, silence, softness, luxery, dashboard you name it is all 
a level above the rest of brands .. I so can imagine the real experience :)﻿

comments.author: MrLiviac

comments.text:
The United States is barely 200 years old, and much of it west of the 
Mississippi has only been developed over the last century. Europe is 
different. Countries there are thousands of years old. Many of the major 
cities (including London and Paris) date to the time of the Roman Empire. 
Some are even older. Many of Europe's highways still follow the routes of 
Roman roads. Try taking a Pete 379 with a 53' trailer through the streets 
of European cities, and you'll just get stuck. Repeatedly.
comments.author: DarqeDestroyer

comments.text:
The only issue i see that carries over from all other models is the gear 
shift lever position for the auto. It is actualy a bit of a pain for 
getting out of the seat and accross into the centre of the cab. A paddle 
shift on the wheel or the door or the arm rest would be the way to go. 
Other than that, it looks very nice, and i hope that the new FH is the 
replacement for our current FH.

comments.author: dsmerak

comments.text:
The new Volvo FH is available with a 13-litre engine (420- 540 hp) and a 
16-litre engine (540-750 hp). The fuel consumption varies very much as it 
depends on the truck specification, engine size, load, driving cycle etc. – 
it is difficult to give one figure. But for a typical European 40/44 ton 
long-haul truck the consumption is probably around 28-35 litre/100 km.
